exampleSentence: Kia ora e hoa!
notes: The most widely known Māori greeting. Can also express gratitude.

exampleSentence: Tēnā koe, e te rangatira.
notes: Formal greeting to one person. 'Koe' is the singular second-person pronoun.

exampleSentence: Tēnā kōrua, e ōku hoa.
exampleTranslation: Greetings to you two, my friends.
notes: Formal greeting to two people. 'Kōrua' is the dual second-person pronoun.

english: greetings to you all (three or more)
exampleSentence: Tēnā koutou, tēnā koutou, tēnā koutou katoa.
exampleTranslation: Greetings, greetings, greetings to you all.
notes: Formal greeting to three or more people. Often repeated three times for emphasis.

exampleSentence: Mōrena! Kei te pēhea koe?
notes: A loanword-influenced greeting used widely in everyday te reo Māori.

exampleSentence: Haere rā, e hoa. Kia pai tō rā.
exampleTranslation: Goodbye, friend. Have a good day.
notes: Said by the person staying to the person departing.

exampleSentence: Ka kite anō, e hoa!
notes: Short form of 'ka kite anō' (see you again). Casual farewell.

exampleSentence: Nau mai, haere mai ki tō mātou marae!
notes: Often paired with 'haere mai' for emphasis: nau mai, haere mai.

exampleSentence: Haere mai ki roto!
notes: A very common welcoming expression, used across Aotearoa.

exampleSentence: Hei konā, e te whānau.
notes: Said by the person leaving to those who are staying behind.

english: vitality, living essence, a greeting of wellbeing
exampleSentence: Mauri ora ki a koutou katoa.
notes: A greeting that acknowledges the mauri (life force) of others.

exampleSentence: Ata mārie, e te whānau.
notes: A gentle morning greeting invoking peacefulness.

exampleSentence: Ko tōku whānau tōku kaha.
notes: A central concept in Māori society encompassing extended family and community.

exampleSentence: Kei te aroha au ki tōku māmā.
Ko tōku pāpā tēnā.
Ko Hine tōku tuakana.
notes: Refers to an older sibling of the same gender. Part of the tuakana-teina relationship.

exampleSentence: Ko Tama tōku teina.
notes: Refers to a younger sibling of the same gender. The teina learns from the tuakana.

exampleSentence: E toru āku mokopuna.
notes: Can refer to grandchildren and further descendants.

exampleSentence: Ko tōku kuia te kaikaranga.
notes: A term of respect for an elderly woman or grandmother.

exampleSentence: Kei te noho tōku koroua ki te kāinga.
exampleTranslation: My grandfather is living at home.
notes: A term of respect for an elderly man or grandfather.

exampleSentence: Ko ia tōku tāne.
notes: Also the name of Tāne-mahuta, the atua of forests and birds.

exampleSentence: He wahine toa ia.
notes: Plural form is 'wāhine'.

exampleSentence: Kei te mamae tōku māhunga.
notes: The head is considered tapu (sacred) in Māori culture.

exampleSentence: He ātaahua ōna kanohi.
notes: Also used figuratively: 'kanohi kitea' means a face that is seen (being present).

exampleSentence: Whakarongo mai ō taringa!
He roa tōna ihu.
notes: The hongi (pressing noses together) is a traditional Māori greeting.

exampleSentence: Kati tō waha!
notes: Can also mean 'to carry' when used as a verb.

exampleSentence: Horoia ō ringa.
Kei te mamae tōku waewae.
Kei te hiakai tōku puku.
notes: Also used in compound words, e.g., 'pukukai' (glutton).

exampleSentence: Kei te mamae tōku tuarā.
Kia kaha tō manawa.
notes: Used in many compound words: 'manawanui' (determination), 'manawaroa' (patience).

exampleSentence: He nui tēnā rākau.
notes: Can also refer to tools, weapons, or any wooden implement.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere mātou ki te moana.
exampleTranslation: We are going to the sea.
notes: Can refer to any large body of water including lakes.

exampleSentence: Ko Ruapehu tōku maunga.
notes: Mountains are often named in mihimihi (introductions) as identity markers.

exampleSentence: Ko Waikato tōku awa.
notes: Rivers are important identity markers in mihimihi (introductions).

exampleSentence: He tapu te whenua.
notes: Also means 'placenta', reflecting the deep connection between people and land.

exampleSentence: Kei te whiti te rā.
notes: Tamanuiterā is the personification of the sun in Māori tradition.

exampleSentence: Kei te tiaho te marama.
notes: Also means 'clear' or 'bright' as an adjective. The Māori calendar is based on lunar months.

exampleSentence: E kite ana au i ngā whetū.
notes: Stars were crucial for Polynesian navigation (whakatere waka).

exampleSentence: He maha ngā kapua i te rangi.
exampleTranslation: There are many clouds in the sky.
notes: Aotearoa means 'land of the long white cloud' (ao-tea-roa).

exampleSentence: Kei te ua i waho.
Kua reri te kai.
notes: One of the most commonly used Māori words in New Zealand English.

exampleSentence: Homai he wai māku.
notes: Also a question word meaning 'who'. Context determines the meaning.

exampleSentence: Kei te pīrangi miraka ahau.
notes: A transliteration from English.

exampleSentence: He reka te parāoa.
notes: Parāoa parai (fried bread) is a well-known Māori food.

exampleSentence: Kei te hī ika tōku pāpā.
notes: Te Ika-a-Māui (the fish of Māui) is the Māori name for the North Island.

exampleSentence: He reka te kūmara.
notes: A staple food brought to Aotearoa by Polynesian voyagers. Proverb: 'Kāore te kūmara e kōrero mō tōna ake reka' (the kūmara does not speak of its own sweetness).

exampleSentence: Homai tētahi āporo.
notes: A transliteration from English.

exampleSentence: Kei te inu tī ahau.
notes: A transliteration from English. Also the name of the cabbage tree (tī kōuka).

exampleSentence: Kei te tunu rīwai au.
notes: Refers to the European potato, distinct from kūmara (sweet potato).

exampleSentence: He pai te huarākau mō te hauora.
notes: From 'hua' (fruit/product) and 'rākau' (tree/plant).

exampleSentence: He whero te motokā.
notes: One of the traditional colours in Māori art and carving.

exampleSentence: He kākāriki te rau o te rākau.
exampleTranslation: The leaf of the tree is green.
notes: Also the name of the native green parakeet (kākāriki). The colour is named after the bird.

exampleSentence: He kikorangi ōna karu.
He kōwhai te whare.
notes: Also the name of the native kōwhai tree, known for its bright yellow flowers.

exampleSentence: He mā te kapua.
notes: Also means 'clean' or 'pure'. Used in 'Aotearoa' — ao-tea-roa (long white cloud).

exampleSentence: He mangu tōna makawe.
He parauri te kurī.
He karaka te rā e tō ana.
notes: Also the name of the native karaka tree (Corynocarpus laevigatus).

exampleSentence: He waiporoporo te putiputi.
notes: Also the name of the native poroporo plant (Solanum aviculare), which has purple flowers.

exampleSentence: He kiwikiwi te rangi i tēnei rā.
He māwhero te putiputi.
notes: From 'mā' (white) and 'whero' (red), literally 'whitish-red'.

exampleSentence: He kahurangi te rangi.
notes: Also means 'precious' or 'esteemed'. Used in the name of pounamu (greenstone) variety 'kahurangi'.

exampleSentence: Kotahi te pukapuka.
notes: 'Kotahi' is the form used when counting things. 'Tahi' is used when counting in sequence.

exampleSentence: E rua ngā kurī.
notes: Also means 'hole' or 'pit' as a noun. Context determines the meaning.

exampleSentence: E toru ngā tamariki.
E whā ngā tūru.
E rima ngā rā i te wiki mahi.
exampleTranslation: There are five days in the work week.
notes: Also means 'hand', reflecting the five fingers.

exampleSentence: E ono ngā āporo kei te kete.
exampleTranslation: There are six apples in the basket.

exampleSentence: E whitu ngā rā o te wiki.
exampleTranslation: There are seven days in the week.

exampleSentence: E waru ngā tamariki i te akomanga.
exampleTranslation: There are eight children in the class.

exampleSentence: E iwa ngā whetū i te ata.
exampleTranslation: There are nine stars in the morning.
notes: Matariki (the Pleiades) is sometimes said to have nine stars visible.

exampleSentence: E tekau ngā matimati o ōku ringa.
exampleTranslation: There are ten fingers on my hands.
notes: 'Ngahuru' is an older word for ten, still used in some dialects.

exampleSentence: E rua rau ngā tāngata i te hui.
exampleTranslation: There are two hundred people at the meeting.
notes: Also means 'leaf'. 'Kotahi rau' = one hundred, 'e rua rau' = two hundred.

exampleSentence: E toru mano ngā tāngata i haere mai.
notes: Can also mean 'a great number' in general.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere au ā te wiki e tū mai nei.
notes: A transliteration from English 'week'.

exampleSentence: He tau hou tēnei.
notes: Also means 'number', 'beloved', or 'to settle'. Context determines meaning.

exampleSentence: I te ata, ka whakatika au.
exampleTranslation: In the morning, I get up.
notes: Also means 'carefully' as an adverb, as in 'ata mārie' (peaceful morning).

exampleSentence: I te ahiahi, ka kai mātou.
Kia pai tō pō.
notes: Te Pō is also a concept in Māori cosmology referring to the realm of darkness and the spirit world.

exampleSentence: Ka kite au i a koe āpōpō.
I haere au ki te toa inanahi.
exampleTranslation: I went to the shop yesterday.

exampleSentence: Me haere tāua ināianei.
Kotahi te hāora ki mua.
notes: A transliteration from English 'hour'. Used when telling the time.

exampleSentence: E rima meneti kei te toe.
notes: A transliteration from English 'minute'.

exampleSentence: Kei te pupuhi te hau.
notes: Also carries a deep spiritual meaning: 'hau' can refer to the vital essence or spirit of a person or gift.

exampleSentence: Kei te heke te hukarere ki runga i te maunga.
exampleTranslation: The snow is falling on the mountain.
notes: From 'huka' (frost/foam) and 'rere' (to fly/fall). Literally 'flying frost'.

exampleSentence: He huka kei runga i te papa.
exampleTranslation: There is frost on the ground.
notes: Can also mean 'foam' or 'froth'. Also used for 'sugar' (huka).

exampleSentence: Titiro! He āniwaniwa kei te rangi.
exampleTranslation: Look! There is a rainbow in the sky.
notes: Rainbows hold spiritual significance in Māori tradition and can be seen as signs from the atua.

exampleSentence: Kei te hiko te uira i te rangi.
exampleTranslation: Lightning is flashing in the sky.
notes: Associated with Tāwhirimātea, the atua of weather and storms.

exampleSentence: Kei te haruru te whatitiri.
notes: Whaitiri is also an important ancestress in Māori mythology, grandmother of Tāwhaki.

exampleSentence: Kei te pōuriuri te ata i te kohu.
exampleTranslation: The morning is dim because of the fog.

exampleSentence: Kei te makariri te rangi i tēnei rā.
notes: Can function as a noun (the cold) or an adjective (cold). Also used to refer to winter.

exampleSentence: Kei te wera te rangi i tēnei rā.
notes: Can also mean 'burnt' when referring to food or skin.

exampleSentence: Kei te oma te kurī i te pāka.
exampleTranslation: The dog is running in the park.
notes: The kurī was the Polynesian dog brought to Aotearoa by early Māori settlers. It is now extinct.

exampleSentence: Kei te moe te ngeru i runga i te moenga.
exampleTranslation: The cat is sleeping on the bed.

exampleSentence: He maha ngā kau i te pāmu.
exampleTranslation: There are many cows on the farm.
notes: Introduced to Aotearoa by European settlers.

exampleSentence: E whitu ngā hipi i te paddock.
exampleTranslation: There are seven sheep in the paddock.
notes: A transliteration from English 'sheep'. Introduced by European settlers.

exampleSentence: Kei te kai te hoiho i te tarutaru.
exampleTranslation: The horse is eating the grass.
notes: A transliteration from English. Horses were highly valued by Māori in the 19th century.

exampleSentence: Kei te waiata te manu i te rākau.
exampleTranslation: The bird is singing in the tree.
notes: Birds are taonga (treasures) under the guardianship of Tāne-mahuta, atua of forests and birds.

exampleSentence: He manu pō te kiwi.
exampleTranslation: The kiwi is a nocturnal bird.
notes: The kiwi is a national symbol of Aotearoa New Zealand. It is a flightless, nocturnal bird found nowhere else in the world.

exampleSentence: Ka kitea te weka i te ngahere.
exampleTranslation: The weka can be seen in the forest.
notes: A flightless native bird known for being bold and curious. Weka were an important food source for Māori.

exampleSentence: He nui ngā waewae o te wheke.
notes: Te Wheke is a model used in Māori health representing the eight tentacles as dimensions of wellbeing.

exampleSentence: Kei te kaukau te tohora i te moana.
exampleTranslation: The whale is swimming in the ocean.
notes: Whales are considered taonga and are associated with many iwi. Whale strandings are significant cultural events.

exampleSentence: He taniwha kei roto i tērā roto, e ai ki te kōrero.
exampleTranslation: There is a taniwha in that lake, according to the story.
notes: Taniwha are supernatural beings that live in deep pools, rivers, and the sea. They can be guardians (kaitiaki) or dangerous.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere au ki te kura.
notes: One of the most common verbs in te reo Māori. Also used in 'haere mai' (welcome) and 'haere rā' (goodbye).

exampleSentence: Kei te inu wai ahau.
Kei te moe ngā tamariki.
notes: Also used in 'moemoeā' (dream/vision).

exampleSentence: Noho ki raro.
notes: A versatile verb that can mean 'sit', 'stay', 'live', or 'remain'.

exampleSentence: E tū! Kia tū koe.
notes: Tūmatauenga (Tū) is the atua of war and people. 'Tū' conveys strength and resolve.

exampleSentence: Kei te oma ngā tamariki i te papa tākaro.
exampleTranslation: The children are running in the playground.

exampleSentence: Kei te kōrero Māori ia.
notes: Can function as both a verb (to speak) and a noun (story, narrative). Central to oral tradition.

exampleSentence: Kei te pānui pukapuka ahau.
notes: Can also be a noun meaning 'notice' or 'announcement'.

exampleSentence: Kei te tuhituhi reta ahau.
notes: A reduplicated form of 'tuhi' (to draw/mark).

exampleSentence: Kei te waiata ngā tauira i te akomanga.
exampleTranslation: The students are singing in the classroom.
notes: Waiata are an integral part of Māori culture, used in ceremonies, celebrations, and to express emotion.

exampleSentence: Kei te kanikani ngā tāngata i te pāti.
exampleTranslation: The people are dancing at the party.
notes: Distinct from traditional Māori performing arts like haka and poi.

exampleSentence: Kei te hari au i tēnei rā.
Kei te pōuri ia mō tōna hoa.
exampleTranslation: She is sad about her friend.
notes: Can also mean dark or overcast when referring to weather.

exampleSentence: Kei te riri a Māmā ki a au.
Kei te mataku te tamaiti i te kurī.
exampleTranslation: The child is scared of the dog.

exampleSentence: He nui tōku aroha ki tōku whānau.
exampleTranslation: My love for my family is great.
notes: Aroha is a deeply important concept in te ao Māori, encompassing love, compassion, empathy, and concern for others.

exampleSentence: He tangata ngākau māhaki a ia.
notes: Ngākau means heart or mind; māhaki means gentle or mild.

exampleSentence: Kei te whakamā ia ki te kōrero i mua i te akomanga.
exampleTranslation: She is shy to speak in front of the class.
notes: Whakamā can range from mild shyness to deep shame depending on context.

exampleSentence: Kei te hīamo ngā tamariki mō te hararei.
exampleTranslation: The children are excited about the holiday.

exampleSentence: Kei te māngere ia i tēnei ata.
notes: Māngere is also the name of a suburb in Auckland.

exampleSentence: Kei te hiakai au. Kei hea te kai?
exampleTranslation: I am hungry. Where is the food?
notes: Hia- is a prefix indicating desire; kai means food. So hiakai literally means desiring food.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere au ki te kāinga.
notes: Kāinga refers to where one lives and can also mean a village or settlement.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere ngā tamariki ki te kura.
exampleTranslation: The children are going to school.
notes: Kura also traditionally means a treasure. Kura kaupapa Māori are Māori-medium schools.

exampleSentence: He nui tō mātou whare.
notes: Whare is used as a base word in many compound words, e.g. whare kai (dining hall), whare moe (bedroom).

exampleSentence: Kei te haere māua ki te toa ki te hoko kai.
exampleTranslation: We (two) are going to the shop to buy food.
notes: Toa also traditionally means a warrior or brave person. Context determines meaning.

exampleSentence: Ka haere mātou ki te whare karakia i te Rātapu.
exampleTranslation: We go to church on Sunday.
notes: Literally means house of prayer. Karakia can refer to prayer, incantation, or blessing.

exampleSentence: Kei te tākaro ngā tamariki i te papa tākaro.
exampleTranslation: The children are playing at the playground.
notes: Papa means a flat surface or ground; tākaro means to play.

exampleSentence: Waiho tō waka ki te tūranga waka.
exampleTranslation: Leave your car at the car park.
notes: Tūranga means a standing place; waka means vehicle or canoe.

exampleSentence: Kei te hōhipera tōku kuia.
exampleTranslation: My grandmother is at the hospital.
notes: A transliteration of the English word hospital.

exampleSentence: Ka tiki pukapuka au i te whare pukapuka.
exampleTranslation: I will get books from the library.
notes: Literally means house of books.

exampleSentence: Ka hui tātou ki te marae ā te Rāhoroi.
exampleTranslation: We will all gather at the marae on Saturday.
notes: The marae is a sacred communal gathering place central to Māori identity.

exampleSentence: Whakamaua ō hū.
He pango ōku tarau.
notes: A transliteration derived from English.

exampleSentence: He whero tōku hāte.
notes: A transliteration of the English word shirt.

exampleSentence: Kawea tō koti, kei makariri.
exampleTranslation: Take your coat, it might be cold.
notes: A transliteration of the English word coat.

exampleSentence: Whakamaua tō pōtae i te rā.
exampleTranslation: Wear your hat in the sun.

exampleSentence: Kei hea ōku tōkena?
notes: A transliteration of the English word stocking.

exampleSentence: He ātaahua tōna pūeru.
Horoia ō kākahu.
notes: Kākahu is the general term for clothing or garments. Traditionally it also referred to cloaks.

exampleSentence: Waiho te kai ki runga i te tēpu.
exampleTranslation: Leave the food on the table.
notes: A transliteration of the English word table.

exampleSentence: E noho ki runga i te tūru.
Haere ki tō moenga, kua pō.
exampleTranslation: Go to your bed, it is night.
notes: Derived from moe (to sleep). Moenga literally means a place for sleeping.

exampleSentence: Kei te tunu kai au i te kīhini.
exampleTranslation: I am cooking food in the kitchen.
notes: A transliteration of the English word kitchen.

exampleSentence: Haere ki tō rūma moe.
notes: A transliteration of the English word room. Rūma moe means bedroom.

exampleSentence: Huakina te tatau.
Huakina te matapihi kia puta te hau.
exampleTranslation: Open the window to let the breeze through.

exampleSentence: Kei hea te wharepaku?
notes: Literally means small house. Traditionally the wharepaku was a separate building.

exampleSentence: Kei te mātakitaki pouaka whakaata ngā tamariki.
notes: Literally means box of reflections. Pouaka means box; whakaata means to reflect.

exampleSentence: Tekau mā tahi ngā tamariki.
notes: Tekau mā = ten and. Add the unit number after mā.

exampleSentence: Tekau mā rua ngā marama o te tau.
exampleTranslation: There are twelve months in the year.

exampleSentence: Tekau mā toru aku tau.
Tekau mā whā ngā rā kua pahure.
Tekau mā rima meneti kei te toe.
Tekau mā ono ngā tāngata i tae mai.
Tekau mā whitu ngā pukapuka.
Tekau mā waru aku tau.
Tekau mā iwa ngā kēmu i tākaro.
E rua tekau ngā tāngata i te hui.
exampleTranslation: There are twenty people at the meeting.
notes: Tens are formed as: number + tekau. E.g. rua tekau = two tens = 20.

exampleSentence: E toru tekau ngā rā o te marama.
exampleTranslation: There are thirty days in the month.

exampleSentence: E whā tekau ōna tau.
E rima tekau paihēneti te utu.
E ono tekau ngā meneti i roto i te hāora.
exampleTranslation: There are sixty minutes in an hour.

exampleSentence: E whitu tekau ngā tāngata i te marae.
exampleTranslation: There are seventy people at the marae.

exampleSentence: E waru tekau ōna tau.
E iwa tekau ngā kiromita ki reira.
exampleTranslation: It is ninety kilometres to there.

exampleSentence: E rua tekau mā tahi ōna tau.
notes: Composite numbers: tens + mā + units. E.g. rua tekau mā tahi = 21.

exampleSentence: E rua tekau mā rima ngā ākonga.
E toru tekau mā tahi ngā rā o tēnei marama.
exampleTranslation: There are thirty-one days in this month.

exampleSentence: E rua rau ngā tāngata i te whare.
exampleTranslation: There are two hundred people in the house.
notes: Hundreds: e + number + rau. 'Kotahi rau' (one hundred) uses kotahi, not tahi.

exampleSentence: E toru rau ngā pukapuka i te whare pukapuka.
exampleTranslation: There are three hundred books in the library.

exampleSentence: E rima rau ngā tāra.
E rua mano ngā tāngata i te hui nui.
exampleTranslation: Two thousand people at the big meeting.
notes: Thousands: e + number + mano.

exampleSentence: E toru mano ngā tāngata i haere mai.
Tekau mano ngā tāngata i te tāone.
exampleTranslation: Ten thousand people in the town.

exampleSentence: Ka tīmata te kura i te Rāhina.
notes: Literally 'day of the moon' (rā + hina). Mane is also used (from English 'Monday').

exampleSentence: Ka haere au ki te toa i te Rātū.
exampleTranslation: I will go to the shop on Tuesday.
notes: Literally 'day of Tū' (the god of war).

exampleSentence: I te Rāapa ka hui tātou.
notes: Literally 'day of Apa' (a corruption of 'Woden' via English).

exampleSentence: Ko te Rāpare te rā pai ki ahau.
Ka wātea au i te Rāmere.
I te Rāhoroi ka haere mātou ki te moana.
exampleTranslation: On Saturday we go to the beach.
notes: Literally 'washing day' (rā + horoi).

exampleSentence: Ko te Rātapu te rā okioki.
exampleTranslation: Sunday is the day of rest.
notes: Literally 'sacred day' (rā + tapu).

exampleSentence: Ko Kohitātea te marama tuatahi o te tau.
exampleTranslation: January is the first month of the year.
notes: Named after the kōhitātea tree whose white flowers bloom in January.

exampleSentence: I te Hui-tanguru ka mahana te rangi.
exampleTranslation: In February the weather is warm.
notes: Named for when seasonal winds blow from the north.

exampleSentence: Ko Poutū-te-rangi te marama o te ngahuru.
exampleTranslation: March is the month of autumn.
notes: Named after a star that appears in March.

exampleSentence: I te Paenga-whāwhā ka tīmata te makariri.
notes: The name refers to the end of harvesting dried crops.

exampleSentence: Ko Haratua te marama o ngā hākari.
exampleTranslation: May is the month of feasts.

exampleSentence: I te Pipiri ka piri ngā tāngata ki te ahi.
exampleTranslation: In June people huddle by the fire.
notes: Pipiri means 'to be close together' — people huddle for warmth in winter.

exampleSentence: Ko Hōngongoi te marama makariri rawa.
notes: Refers to the earth being dormant in the cold of winter.

exampleSentence: I te Here-turi-kōkā ka tīmata te mahana anō.
exampleTranslation: In August the warmth begins again.

exampleSentence: Ko Mahuru te marama o te kōanga.
exampleTranslation: September is the month of spring.
notes: The name relates to the warming of the earth.

exampleSentence: I te Whiringa-ā-nuku ka tupu ngā tipu.
notes: Literally 'turning of the earth' — the earth turns towards warmth.

exampleSentence: Ko Whiringa-ā-rangi te marama o te raumati.
exampleTranslation: November is the month of summer.
notes: Literally 'turning of the sky' — the sky turns towards summer.

exampleSentence: Ko Hakihea te marama whakamutunga o te tau.
exampleTranslation: December is the last month of the year.
notes: The name refers to the harvest of early crops.

exampleSentence: I te kōanga ka puāwai ngā tipu.
notes: From 'kō' (to plant) — the planting season.

exampleSentence: I te raumati ka haere mātou ki te moana.
exampleTranslation: In summer we go to the sea.

exampleSentence: I te ngahuru ka hinga ngā rau.
notes: Also an older word for ten. Associated with harvest time.

exampleSentence: I te hōtoke ka hukarere i runga i te maunga.
exampleTranslation: In winter it snows on the mountain.

exampleSentence: Ko te kurī tēnā.
notes: Definite singular article. Used before singular nouns.

exampleSentence: Ko ngā tamariki ēnā.
notes: Definite plural article. The plural form of 'te'.

exampleSentence: He aha tēnei? He pukapuka.
exampleTranslation: What is this? It is a book.
notes: Indefinite article. Used for unspecified nouns. Also used in classificatory sentences.

exampleSentence: I kite au i tētahi manu.
notes: Indefinite specific article. Used when referring to a particular but unspecified thing.

exampleSentence: Ka haere au ki te kura.
notes: Directional preposition indicating movement towards. Also means 'to say'.

exampleSentence: I noho au i te kāinga.
notes: Locative for past tense. Also a past tense marker before verbs.

exampleSentence: Kei te kura ngā tamariki.
notes: Present tense locative. 'Kei te' before a verb = present continuous tense.

exampleSentence: Hei āpōpō tātou hui ai.
notes: Future tense locative preposition.

exampleSentence: Ko Aotearoa tōku whenua.
notes: Used to identify or emphasize. Essential in mihimihi (introductions).

exampleSentence: Nō Ōtautahi au.
notes: Indicates origin or belonging in past/neutral contexts.

exampleSentence: Nā wai tēnei pukapuka?
notes: Indicates possession or agent. 'Nā' for things near the speaker.

exampleSentence: He koha tēnei mō koe.
exampleTranslation: This is a gift for you.
notes: Preposition meaning 'for' or 'about'. Used for future purpose.

exampleSentence: Māu e mahi.
exampleTranslation: It is for you to do.
notes: Agent preposition. Not to be confused with 'mā' meaning 'white' (colour).

exampleSentence: Ko au tēnei.
notes: 'Au' and 'ahau' are both used for 'I/me'. 'Au' is shorter and more common in casual speech.

exampleSentence: Nō hea koe?
notes: Second person singular pronoun.

exampleSentence: Kei te haere ia ki te kura.
notes: Third person singular pronoun. Te reo Māori does not distinguish gender in pronouns.

exampleSentence: Ka haere māua ki te toa.
exampleTranslation: We two (not you) will go to the shop.
notes: First person dual exclusive. Refers to the speaker and one other, but NOT the listener.

exampleSentence: Ka haere tāua ki te moana.
exampleTranslation: Let's go (you and I) to the sea.
notes: First person dual inclusive. Refers to the speaker AND the listener.

exampleSentence: Ka haere kōrua ki hea?
notes: Second person dual pronoun.

exampleSentence: Kei te kai rāua.
notes: Third person dual pronoun.

exampleSentence: Ka waiata mātou.
notes: First person plural exclusive. Three or more people, NOT including the listener.

exampleSentence: Ka kai tātou!
notes: First person plural inclusive. Three or more people, INCLUDING the listener.

exampleSentence: Kei te pēhea koutou?
notes: Second person plural pronoun. Three or more people.

exampleSentence: Kei te mahi rātou i te māra.
exampleTranslation: They are working in the garden.
notes: Third person plural pronoun. Three or more people.

exampleSentence: He tangata pai ia.
notes: One of the most important words in te reo. Plural: tāngata.

exampleSentence: He tamaiti pai ia.
notes: Irregular plural: tamariki (children). One of the most common irregular plurals.

exampleSentence: Ko ia tōku matua.
notes: Plural: mātua (parents). Also used respectfully for elders.

exampleSentence: Ka haere mātou i runga i te waka.
exampleTranslation: We will travel on the canoe.
notes: Waka can refer to canoe, car, or any vehicle. 'Waka hourua' = double-hulled canoe. Central to Māori identity and migration stories.

exampleSentence: Kia ora koe!
notes: The root of 'kia ora' (be well/hello). Also in 'mauri ora' (vitality) and 'whare ora' (wellness centre).

exampleSentence: He taonga tēnei mōku.
exampleTranslation: This is a treasure for me.
notes: Mō (for) + ku (me). Used for future purpose or intended recipient.

exampleSentence: He koha tēnei māu.
exampleTranslation: This is a gift for you.
notes: Mā (for/by) + u (you). The agent or beneficiary form of 'you'.

exampleSentence: He kai tēnei mōna.
notes: Mō (for) + na (him/her).

exampleSentence: He rā whakahirahira tēnei mō tātou.
exampleTranslation: This is an important day for us all.
notes: Mō (for) + tātou (us all, inclusive).

exampleSentence: Nōku tēnei whare.
notes: Nō (of/from) + ku (me). Indicates possession or origin.

exampleSentence: Nāu tēnei pukapuka?
notes: Nā (by/belonging to) + u (you).

exampleSentence: Nōna tēnei kurī.
notes: Nō (of/from) + na (him/her).

exampleSentence: Homai ki a au.
notes: Ki (to/towards) + a (personal article) + au (me). The 'a' is needed before personal pronouns.

exampleSentence: Ka haere mai au ki a koe.
notes: Ki (to/towards) + a (personal article) + koe (you).

exampleSentence: Kōrerohia ki a ia.
notes: Ki (to/towards) + a (personal article) + ia (him/her).

exampleSentence: I riro i a au te taonga.
exampleTranslation: The treasure was obtained by me.
notes: I (at/from/by) + a (personal article) + au (me). Past tense location or agent.

exampleSentence: I rongo au i a koe.
notes: I (at/from/by) + a (personal article) + koe (you).

exampleSentence: Kei tata te toa.
notes: Used with ki for 'near to': tata ki a koe = near you.

exampleSentence: Kei tawhiti te marae.
notes: Used with i for 'far from': tawhiti i a mātou = far from us.

exampleSentence: Kei roto i te whare ia.
notes: Locative noun. 'Ki roto' = into, 'i roto' = inside, 'kei roto' = is inside. Also means 'lake'.

exampleSentence: Haere ki waho.
notes: Locative noun. 'Ki waho' = to outside, 'i waho' = outside, 'kei waho' = is outside.

exampleSentence: Kei runga i te tēpu te pukapuka.
exampleTranslation: The book is on top of the table.
notes: Locative noun. 'Ki runga' = onto/up, 'i runga' = on top of, 'kei runga' = is on top.

exampleSentence: Kei raro i te tēpu te kurī.
exampleTranslation: The dog is under the table.
notes: Locative noun. 'Ki raro' = downwards, 'i raro' = below, 'kei raro' = is underneath.

exampleSentence: Kei mua i te whare te waka.
exampleTranslation: The car is in front of the house.
notes: Locative noun. 'I mua' = in front of, before (in time). 'Ki mua' = to the front.

exampleSentence: Kei muri i te whare te māra.
exampleTranslation: The garden is behind the house.
notes: Locative noun. 'I muri' = behind, after. 'Ki muri' = to the back.
